Award.AbstractNarration:
Many practical and mathematical problems can be described by polynomial inequalities. These are algebraic inequalities whose variables (unknowns) represent numbers. Because their importance, polynomial inequalities have been studied intensely for many centuries. Matrix inequalities, algebraic equations whose variables are matrices, also appear in many applied areas, such as linear systems engineering, and mathematical fields. A key difference between polynomial and matrix inequalities is that for matrices X and Y, unlike real numbers, it can happen that XY and YX are not the same and if X and Y are "positive", XY need not be "positive". A major theme of this project is the development of a mathematical theory of matrix inequalities with an emphasis on convexity. A set is convex if the line segment joining any two points in the set lies entirely in the set. While it is easy to draw pictures of convex sets in two variables, the notion makes sense and is immensely important in the cases where there are a large number of variables, for instance minimizing cost or in design problems where it is crucial to identifying worst case performance. In many settings, when searching over a convex set, there is a unique minimum (or worst case) and there are very reliable computer algorithms to find the minimum. On the other hand, when searching for a minimum over a set that is not convex it is difficult to be certain that the minimum, and not a value that is simply smaller than those nearby, has been found. The solution set of a linear matrix inequality is convex, but in general solution sets to matrix inequalities are not. A goal of the principal investigator and his collaborators is to determine when the solution set of a matrix inequality is convex, can be converted in a tractable way to, or approximated reasonably by, a convex set described in some fashion by a linear matrix inequality.

This project will contribute to the mathematical foundations of convex matrix inequalities, developing the subject both in parallel to semialgebraic geometry and as a non-linear version of the theory of operator systems and spaces and completely positive/contractive maps. Motivation flows from the deep scientific interactions with applications such as engineering systems theory. It will advances the understanding of both linear matrix inequalities, now standard tools in science and engineering, and matrix inequalities that arise in systems engineering problems, particular for many of those that arise from a signal flow diagram. An important aim is to determine and automate the identification of matrix inequalities with convex solution sets, mapping a non-convex solution set to a convex one (currently done on an ad-hoc basis for some special cases in the systems engineering literature), and otherwise approximating non-convex solution sets by convex ones. The methods employed involve ideas from functional analysis, operator theory, complex analysis and several complex variables, operator systems and spaces, completely positive maps, semidefinite programming and semialgebraic geometry. Conversely, a significant aspect of this proposal is the development of techniques and results that contribute to the theories of operator systems, spaces and algebras and completely positive maps and of (freely) noncommutative analogs of the theory of analytic functions in one and several variables. In another direction, the distinction between positive and completely positive maps on natural operator algebras of functions arising in one and several complex variables will be investigated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Convexity is a fundamental geometric notion in mathematics and its applications. It is particularly important in optimization, since convexity often leads to numerically stable and tractable problems.  A set S is convex if the line connecting any two points in S is again in S.

Many problems in science and engineering are modeled by systems of polynomial inequalities in several unknowns. Classically, the unknowns are real or complex numbers, inequality is in the sense of positive real number, and the solution (feasible) set of a system of inequalities is a semialgebraic set. The theory of these inequalities is known as semialgebraic geometry.

It turns out that in many areas of mathematics, science and engineering the unknowns are matrices, rather than real or complex numbers, inequality is in the sense of positive definite matrix, rather than positive real number, and the coefficients of the polynomials are matrices.   If X and Y are square matrices of the same size, XY need not be the same as YX. Accordingly, polynomials, and more generally rational functions, in matrix unknowns are called noncommutative, synonymously free, polynomials (rational functions). The resulting polynomial inequalities are matrix inequalities, MIs. The solution (feasible) set of a matrix inequality is a free semialgebraic set.

In the classical (commutative) case, the solution set of a system of affine linear polynomial inequalities with real coefficients is a convex polytope. Optimizing a linear objective function over a convex polytope is linear programming, a standard technique in quantitative disciplines.  When the affine linear polynomials have matrix coefficients, the resulting inequality is a Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI).  The solution set of an LMI is a spectrahedron.  Semidefinite programming (SDP) - a relatively new subfield of convex optimization - refers to optimizing a linear objective function over a spectrahedron. With recent advances in interior point methods, SDP is a tractable and powerful generalization of linear programming.  In the case of matrix unknowns, the natural notion of convexity is called matrix convexity and the free semialgebraic set determined by an LMI is a matrix convex set called a free spectrahedron. Results from an earlier award showed that a matrix convex free semialgebraic set is free spectrahedron. Results from this award, discussed below, address the fundamental question of recognizing when the solution set of a MI is matrix convex.

Certain systems engineering problems governed by a signal flow diagram lead to matrix inequalities; and matrix convex sets, LMIs and MIs overlap significantly with the mathematical theories of operator systems and spaces, and completely positive maps which form the foundation of quantum information theory among other subjects.

This project continued the development of free semialgebraic, the theory of polynomial, and more generally rational, inequalities in matrix unknowns, with an emphasis on convexity. Results from this award included the following. A free semialgebraic set determined by an irreducible hermitian free polynomial p is matrix convex if and only if p has degree two and a very specific form. Dropping the irreducibility assumption, an algorithm was developed to determine if a given polynomial p produces a free spectrahedron, and if so, this algorithm explicitly constructs the corresponding LMI.  A free analytic function is a natural generalization of a free rational function.  Under rather general hypotheses, triples (A,B,f) of free spectrahedra A and B and a free analytic function f mapping A bijectively to B were classified. They have a highly algebraic form. A notable family of free spectrahedra that fall outside of this classification have rotational symmetry.  Initial results suggest that if A and B have rotational symmetry and satisfy an additional natural hypothesis, then the only bijective free analytic maps between them are in fact linear. Many of the foundational results surrounding convexity in free semialgebraic geometry were extended to the setting of matrix inequalities in two classes of variables, say a and x, with some partial convexity. For instance, in certain engineering problems, it is natural  to ask for convexity in the x variables for fixed a variables.

Human resource development was also an outcome of this award. Two graduate students worked on aspects of this project.  One received her PhD under the PIs direction this (2021) Spring. The other visited the University of Florida and worked with the PI and other faculty during the Spring 2019 semester.  A third graduate student received his PhD under the PIs direction in 2019, working on problems related to, but not directly a part of, this award. Finally, a student began a University of Florida sponsored undergraduate research project this (2021) Spring directed by the PI studying bijective free mappings between free spectrahedra in a class of domains with a large amount of circular symmetry.
